Merged. Thanks!!
üéâ  üëç
@mariogarcia You are the man buddy! :tada:

Yeahhh!!!!! :smiley: :tada: :confetti_ball: thanks @ilopmar I'm really happy to help version 2.5.0 to be a little bit closer. But of course this is teamwork, thanks to @bsideup and @paulk-asert as well.

@christoph-frick  Thanks for putting this together, it's been an outstanding request for 6+ years. There seems to be enough support for this feature, and only the naming discussion is holding it up.  If you don't mind changing the method name to tap, then it seems like this could be merged.

@graemerocher @paulk-asert thanks for all the feedback.  I think I have addressed all the points in the latest commit 16ef9c9.  I pulled out the `Generator` (and `Options` builder) from `JsonOutput` and made it its own type along with a default implementation.  I have also added an extensibility test as Paul suggested.
I removed the diamond operator and preserved the method signature and parameter names of `collectImportedSymbols` to make the fix available to 2.4.x.
PR merged for 2.4.x and 2.5, thanks!
PR merged, thanks!
@MarcusJL if you have any feedback on #371 I'd be interested to know since you have looked at this problem.

+1, This looks like a nice solution for me and would also cover #433.
For which release would that be planned?
I agree #371 will solve this issue in a more generic way. Can be closed if #371 is merged.
@MarcusJL thanks for taking a look at this, I appreciate it.  Unless there is other feedback in the next week or so I'll plan on merging this into master, so this would be for the 2.5 release.
@jwagenleitner thanks, that sounds great!

@paulk-asert 
Paul, any problem on the ordering?
+1, nice work
+1, I tested and this also fixes [GROOVY-6468](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-6468).
@paulk-asert ping :)
Sorry, it's about 4 or 5th on my todo list to look at. Hopefully next week.
@paulk-asert ok, sure, just pinging :)

IMHO `doto` is ugly name.
I vote for `apply`.
@dovchinnikov `apply` means at least in python, javascript, clojure: take a function and a list and run that function with each element of the list as argument to that function.

@christoph-frick It doesn't mean anything in Groovy :) Groovy already has `each`. 
Btw Kotlin uses `apply`.
"apply" makes a lot of sense to me.  Now that I know that Kotlin has the exact same feature named apply, it seems to me to be the obvious choice.

Hi Paul, I hope I'm not doing a mistake by writing here. Anyway I had a look to the commit and your new test method is `testSortMethodsWithComparatorAcceptingSubclass` and it tests for a `Comparator<? extends CharSequence>`, IMHO, however, the point of the bug report is that those methods should accept a Comparator accepting SUPERclass, so that you can sort, say, an `Iterable<String>` with a `Comparator<Object>` (which, as an example, may sort based on the object `toString()` output,).

Hi Mauro, writing here is fine! I misunderstood what you were after - adding a failing test to your issue is a good way to remove ambiguity! :-) OK, so there are two issues. Firstly, the DGM signatures needed changing which is what I have added so far. But there is also a bug in the type checker at the moment which now needs fixing. It still reports an error but shouldn't for the case you are after even after the signature changes.

Hi Christoph, I think this is useful and we should go ahead - we mostly seem to be stalled on naming. Any chance you can rename to 'apply' to match Kotlin's naming scheme and add the tests that Jochen suggested and rebase? Once done I'll send an email to the users mailing list to get any final thoughts on naming alternatives (a final rename is easy if needed) and I can help get this through into 2.5. We hope to release a beta shortly.

If you also wanted to add in some doco, feel free otherwise I'll do that. [search for 'Using with() for repeated operations on the same bean' within style-guide.adoc to find the right place and no I don't know why it is only there but that will do].
PR merged, thanks!

Should this line be using the generator instead?
 https://github.com/apache/groovy/blob/master/subprojects/groovy-json/src/main/java/groovy/json/StreamingJsonBuilder.java#L731
Yes I think that method was added fairly recently and was missed, the generator should replace all calls to `JsonOutput.toJson`.

I am really sorry, for causing so much turmoil.  That patch was not considered
worthy for a year now and quite honestly: I don't want my name to be associated
with a function `apply`, that does not do, what is expected of it
(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apply).  

For me, Groovy naming is odd, since I am no Ruby developer in the first place,
but I would consider it the Groovy heritage for picking a name for a function.
So `tap` makes no sense to me -- same as e.g. `inject` makes no sense to me
(`fold`, `reduce` do) -- but if Ruby developers know that term, I am willing
to learn.

Since to me Kotlin has its influence from Groovy, "back-porting" a Kotlin name
-- that feels absolutely wrong to me -- is not fine with me.  So I'd rather
close this ticket now. So one of the proponents for `apply` can do their own
patch for fame and glory ;)

Hi Christoph, I was planning on getting more feedback on the name in the mailing list. I was just suggesting `apply` as the holding pattern since there seems to be as much or more acceptance of that name than `doto`. Kotlin doesn't seem to have confusion between the specific with-like apply and the traditional functional version but that is one of the points that would be debated in the mailing list. I understand if you want to withdraw but after the debate, the name may still end up being doto, who knows.

Would any of these names work for you: `withThis`, `auto`, `autoWith`, `asThis`?

P.S. inject and collect come from Smalltalk not Ruby.

P.P.S. and it's not the case that your PR was ever considered 'not worthy', it's just that naming is hard and we prefer to delay and get right rather than rush and make further naming even harder down the track.
Thanks! That looks good. I'll send an email to the users list and ask for feedback on the name.
+1 for `withThis`

Would like to know what you think about removing the `Object convert(Object)` method and just leave the `Object convert(Object,String)` method on the Converter, doesn't seem like both are needed as long as it documented that the key may be null.
@jwagenleitner Makes sense to me
PR merged, thanks!
@paulk-asert ping ;)

It seems that some errors occurred because of 503 in installing jdk and I don't know how to rerun the building.All tests do have passed.

[https://travis-ci.org/apache/groovy/jobs/174813683](https://travis-ci.org/apache/groovy/jobs/174813683)

Might just be a temporary problem, if you squash the commits and force push it should kick off the TravisCI again.

I'm afraid I can't squash the commits because they are across a merge - I should have synced my master with upstream instead of merging my own branched into it. 

But it doesn't matter, I just closed and reopened this PR to trigger travis build.

Hey Christoph, the general consensus seems to be tap plus with(true) as an alternative option (basically a variant with an extra "boolean returning" parameter). Plus we need a little bit of asciidoc doco. Are you happy to do either of these or are you happy for me to take the PR as is and make the necessary tweaks?
@paulk-asert I have added some documentation at the spot you suggested earlier. Feel free to take over from here - or let me know, if something is missing I can do.
I'm for `tap`. I think `withThis` is ugly,  `with(true)` seems like a hack to change the behaviour of an existing method.

@christoph-frick thanks, I'll take it from here - will let you know if there are any problems

@graemerocher yes, `with(true)` is there for users that find `tap` a totally foreign name and to help link normal `with` and `tap` conceptually. Using `tap` will be preferred because we can pass along better typing information with its signature.
Proposed PR and some minor tweaks applied. Thanks everyone for the contribution, discussion and patience.
Thanks!
not sure this will do. You do want the parameter types and number of parameters depending on the closure you memoized. What happens if you keep those as in the original but do the call/doCall change?

Thanks.  I added back setting the parameters and added a test for param count/types.  Also made the same doCall change to the `SoftReferenceMemoizeFunction` to make sure it'll pick up the right method.

Because of [GROOVY-4482](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GROOVY-4482) I wonder if it would be safer to leave the `call(Object...)` method in place and have `doCall` delegate to it in order to avoid the `invokeMethod` that `Closure.call` uses.  Not sure how to test against GAE.
I went ahead and left the original `call(...)` and just added a `doCall(...)` that delegates to call.
I have to rework one test before committing due to different field orderings between jdk 7 and 8 which are affecting the toString() value used in a test.
Thanks!
Still needs a test but early feedback welcome.
+1, this looks good. Worth merging into 2_4_X before I cut the next release?
Thanks for reviewing Paul.  I don't think it's worth trying to merge into 2_4_X before the release since it's just a minor improvement and not worth the risk of introducing any problems.
Thanks!
Should be fixed by PR #477.

Thanks - merged.

Just as a general note, Apache encourages projects to not include @author tags in their source code. Apart from reducing maintenance, it is meant to increase the community feeling of ownership of the whole codebase. After all, you can find out who wrote which lines from git, so it isn't a huge loss of information. So, a PR that deleted the authors would have been just as good - we try hard to make sure that anyone who has contributed anything of any consequence is mentioned in the pom - and the two authors in this file are.

In any case, we haven't adopted that policy globally yet, just slowly heading in that direction - so I merged your PR, since it is better to not have the error.
Do we have the priority documented anywhere or just in the code? We don't have test coverage for your example.

I think no documentation and no test. I extracted the example from the code you changed actually to show you what your change will affect. In my opinion the get/set path needs to be removed, but that is another topic. The trouble is that get/set in the MOP is in general very badly documented. So it might or it might not be, that your change is a breaking one. Well no, it is a breaking change in terms of semantics, but if real world examples will be badly affected by this? no idea. But I have another example:
> class A extends HashMap {
    public foo
}
>
> def a = new A()
a.x = 1
assert a.x == 1
a.foo = 2
assert a.@foo == 2
assert a.foo == null
assert a == [x:1]

the last three asserts will all fail.

@blackdrag These three asserts fail in 2.4.8
@jwagenleitner That does the trick - I modified the PR
@paulk-asert I might have used a pre 2.4.8 program to test my two scripts. But I can see, that your new version makes both pass again. So +1

After looking at this pullrequest I am not sure if this does not go a bit over board. It means all the calls to call() and call(Object) will then go to call(Object[]) instead. The problem with this now is, that call(Object[]) will use a dynamic method call to call the appropriate doCall method, while in the presented cases call() and call(Object) do direct method calls. In other words we would loose a lot of performance here. I also think that part of the problem gets "covered up" by now using a different invocation path in the StaticMethodcallWriter. The key element should be isCallOnClosure, as has bee correctly identified. But if we applied for example this patch here [pr460.diff.txt](https://github.com/apache/groovy/files/736549/pr460.diff.txt) it will make the supplied test case work... while not giving up on the call semantics

First of all I advice doing much smaller pull requests and split a bug change and a refactoring into separate ones. This will very much help to reduce the time needed till somebody does a review. 

But besides that +1
Would be nice to see Paul comment on this, but I think we I can a +1 on this
I think I am now -1 on this change
@blackdrag Yes, you're right.
**Note to self:** `git branch --all --contains` 7c735bfc1807df4e8fa44f02958c7a000634b6de
Wrt ClassInfoDeadlockTest#L58: should we make it a manual test?

Since this test can take minutes to run, requires several threads and performs GC I don't think it should be mixed in with the normal unit tests.  But it would be nice to have a way to include tests like these (spin up threads, GC, etc).  Is there a certain way manual tests are implemented, would it be the benchmark or performance tests?

maybe we could add this to the performance tests part, yes

But frankly I am surprised if your change solves the problem, since it looks to me as if it is the same reference queue, that is being used when the error happens. Also in the reference queue itself there is no visible locking, the locks that seem to cause the problem stem from our code itself. How about changing ManagedLinkedList to use a ConcurrentLinkedQueue inside? Then we will not have to synchronize on it anymore.

Any particular concern @blackdrag? I like very much the many options this opens up but also wish there was a nicer way to implement. I just can't think of any other way to implement to allow this feature.

>maybe we could add this to the performance tests part, yes

I will take a closer look at that sub-project and see if I can work in this test.

>But frankly I am surprised if your change solves the problem, since it looks to me as if it is the same reference queue, that is being used when the error happens

The new `ReferenceBundle#newWeakBundle` method creates a new `ReferenceQueue` on each call, so now the queue for the `GroovyClassValuePreJava7` and `GlobalClassSet` would be separate.  No longer would adding an element to the set possibly trigger a remove from the map.  Given that do you still believe this will not solve the problem?

>How about changing ManagedLinkedList to use a ConcurrentLinkedQueue inside? Then we will not have to synchronize on it anymore.

That sounds like a good idea, how about I add a todo comment for now and I can work on submitting a PR for that soon?  I would want to put some tests around it and that may take some time.  And I think it would be good to make sure this issue gets fixed for 2.4.9.

Only concern I could see is that removal time may be more.  Now the Element is a ManagedReference and it can just un-link itself, with the CLQ it would have to walk the list to find the ManagedReference (used to wrap the real value) to remove.  And the time it takes to remove elements can impact the time it takes to add elements when there are references to clean up.  Overall probably not significant given the better locking in CLQ for adds over having to synchronize as is done now.

>>     But frankly I am surprised if your change solves the problem, since it looks to me as if it is the same reference queue, that is being used when the error happens
> 
> The new ReferenceBundle#newWeakBundle method creates a new ReferenceQueue on each call, so now the queue for the GroovyClassValuePreJava7 and GlobalClassSet would be separate. No longer would adding an element to the set possibly trigger a remove from the map. Given that do you still believe this will not solve the problem?

Even if you have one queue or GroovyClassValuePreJava7 and GlobalClassSet, you still have a ManagedLinkedList, which you add and remove elements from. And each time you add, you potentially remove. The only thing different to before is that the ReferenceQueue will not be shared with another ManagedLinkedList. But the lock in ClassInfo is on the list and the other lock is on GroovyClassValuePreJava7Segment. Those will stay. The only thing changing is that the remove is done with a different timing in my opinion. You would now for example need at least 500 ClassInfos before we start checking for orphaned values.
 
>     How about changing ManagedLinkedList to use a ConcurrentLinkedQueue inside? Then we will not have to synchronize on it anymore.
> 
> That sounds like a good idea, how about I add a todo comment for now and I can work on submitting a PR for that soon? I would want to put some tests around it and that may take some time. And I think it would be good to make sure this issue gets fixed for 2.4.9.

sure
 
> Only concern I could see is that removal time may be more. Now the Element is a ManagedReference and it can just un-link itself, with the CLQ it would have to walk the list to find the ManagedReference (used to wrap the real value) to remove. And the time it takes to remove elements can impact the time it takes to add elements when there are references to clean up. Overall probably not significant given the better locking in CLQ for adds over having to synchronize as is done now.

hmm... he alternative would be to change ManagedLinkedList to use a CAS style approach. I think that is not all that difficult to do for a linked list... but is of course source for new errors too.

>The only thing different to before is that the ReferenceQueue will not be shared with another ManagedLinkedList. But the lock in ClassInfo is on the list and the other lock is on GroovyClassValuePreJava7Segment.

I believe the key difference is that the `ManagedLinkedList` used by `GlobalClassSet` no longer shares a `ReferenceQueue` with the `ManagedConcurrentMap` (subclass `GroovyClassValuePreJava7`).  It is ok for the list (which is synchronized) to remove it's own entries on add.  The problem occurred because by sharing a `ReferenceQueue` the list could also try to remove entries from the map.

>You would now for example need at least 500 ClassInfos before we start checking for orphaned values.

That is a good point and I hadn't considered the threshold setting.  Running `println org.codehaus.groovy.reflection.ClassInfo.size()` from the command line returns ~200, it jumps to ~900 if I run the same command in `GroovyConsole`.  Maybe a value of 200 would be a better threshold setting for `newWeakBundle`.

Though maybe none of it is needed if `ManagedLinkedList` is changed to a non-blocking CLQ.  I'm just not sure what new problems that might introduce and if the weakly consistent iterator would work ok for the `modifiedExpandos` `ManagedLinkedList` (I suspect it wouldn't be a problem).

@blackdrag @paulk-asert 
I've reviewed the PR. +1 from me to merge it as soon as possible :)
Yeah, not sure why the mailing list notifications sometimes do that.
Thanks Amanda, PR merged.

first of all I think I can give this a +1, but the code makes me now wonder if we really do the right thing with flow typing here. I would not have expected the information if kkk is int or String on the accessed variable, which should be the definition. I remember I had an unsatisfying discussion about this with Cedric in the past already. But changing that is out of scope for this PR in my opinion and maybe it is just me not understanding something too

Hi Jochen, yep agree that other parts need to be further investigated to make sure we have the correct behavior - I think it is wrong in some cases too. But my attempts to change things in the StaticTypeCheckingVisitor seemed to be impacting too many things so this was the minimal change to fix the current issue.
As suggested, I opened an alternative PR #489 that uses a `ManagedConcurrentLinkedQueue` to avoid the need to use synchronized blocks.
